before_improvement: Recently, object-centric representation learning has attracted much attention and multiple outstanding works have been summarized (Yuan et al., 2022). For example, the methods, such as AIR (Eslami et al., 2016), GMIOO (Yuan et al., 2019), SPACE (Lin et al., 2019), Slot Attention (Locatello et al., 2020), GENESIS-v2 (Engelcke et al., 2021), SLATE (Singh et al., 2022), DINOSAUR (Seitzer et al., 2023) etc., work well on the static scene. The methods, such as SQAIR (Kosiorek et al., 2018), SCALOR (Jiang et al., 2019), G-SWM (Lin et al., 2020), etc., learn better compositional scene representations by modeling the motions and relationships of objects in the scene. The methods, such as SIMONE (Kabra et al., 2021), MuMON (Li et al., 2020), OCLOC (Yuan et al., 2022), focus on observing the scene from multiple viewpoints. The methods, such as SAVi (Kipf et al., 2022), SAVi++ (Elsayed et al., 2022), STEVE (Singh et al., 2022), apply object-centric learning to videos. Despite the proficiency of the above methods in extracting object-centric representations, they still have some limitations in processing complex scenes. On the one hand, methods such as Slot Attention, OCLOC, and SIMONE cannot segment the object in the complex scenes well. On the other hand, methods such as DINOSAUR and STEVE face difficulties constructing individual object images through their corresponding representations to obtain the gratifying performance of decomposition on complex scenes.

after_improvement: In recent years, object-centric representation learning has gained significant traction within the field of computer science, particularly in the context of understanding and interpreting complex visual scenes. This area encompasses a variety of methodologies aimed at learning representations that focus on individual objects within a scene, rather than the scene as a whole. Notable approaches include AIR (Eslami et al., 2016) and GMIOO (Yuan et al., 2019), which excel in static scenes, as well as methods like SQAIR (Kosiorek et al., 2018) and SCALOR (Jiang et al., 2019), which enhance compositional scene representations by modeling object interactions and movements. Furthermore, techniques such as SIMONE (Kabra et al., 2021) and OCLOC (Yuan et al., 2022) leverage multi-view observations to improve representation learning. However, despite the advancements made by these methods, challenges remain, particularly in the segmentation of objects within complex scenes and the reconstruction of individual object images. For instance, while Slot Attention and SIMONE struggle with effective segmentation in intricate environments, DINOSAUR and STEVE encounter difficulties in accurately reconstructing individual objects from their learned representations. Addressing these limitations is crucial, as effective object-centric representation learning not only enhances our understanding of visual scenes but also has far-reaching implications for applications in robotics, autonomous systems, and artificial intelligence.
